title: iCub Tech Docs
summary: We'd like to let you know that we have just published the iCub Tech Docs, which is by now a handful of instructions that you may find helpful when fiddling with the iCub tendons, especially when you need to replace broken parts.
description:
Hey @robotology/everyone üëã 


We'd like to let you know that we have just published the [**`iCub Tech Docs`**][1], which is by now a handful of instructions that you may find helpful when fiddling with the iCub tendons, especially when you need to replace broken parts. 


Further, the same website provides a list of mechanical upgrade kits you can request for your iCub. 


These new resources do complement our official documentation and are meant to be ever-growing so that they will likely encompass other important topics in the near future. 


[Contributions][2] in terms of fixes and new additions are very welcome and very easy to do through [forks and pull-requests][3]. 


Stay tuned üéß 


[1]: https://github.com/icub-tech-iit/documentation 
[2]: https://github.com/icub-tech-iit/documentation/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md 
[3]: https://guides.github.com/activities/forking

title: iDynTree 1.1 Release
summary: DynTree 1.1.0 was released today and is now available
description:
iDynTree 1.1.0 was released today and is now available for download at: https://github.com/robotology/idyntree/releases/tag/v1.1.0 . 


As iDynTree adheres to [Semantic Versioning](https://semver.org/spec/v2.0.0.html), the 1.1 is a feature release that is backward compatible with iDynTree 1.0 . 


## Release Highlights  


This new release introduce two new features: 


#### New MATLAB based visualizer 


A new MATLAB iDynTree visualizer (https://github.com/robotology/idyntree/pull/682, https://github.com/robotology/idyntree/pull/668) has been added to the iDynTree's [high-level-wrappers](https://github.com/robotology/idyntree/tree/v1.1.0/bindings/matlab/%2BiDynTreeWrappers). ![image17](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1857049/84040869-753e4500-a9a3-11ea-9c3e-81dfaf1ec505.gif) 


A tutorial on how to use this new MATLAB visualizer is available in the https://github.com/robotology/idyntree/tree/v1.1.0/bindings/matlab/%2BiDynTreeWrappers#matlab-native-visualization . 


Thanks a lot to Francisco Andrade (@fjandrad) that implemented this feature in https://github.com/robotology/idyntree/pull/668 and https://github.com/robotology/idyntree/pull/682 . 


####  iDynTree's InverseKinematics MATLAB and Python bindings 


The iDynTree's InverseKinematics class has been added to the iDynTree's bindings, so it is now usable from MATLAB and Python bindings. See the  following snippet to have an idea on how to use `iDynTree.InverseKinematics` in MATLAB: 


 ~~~matlab


ik = iDynTree.InverseKinematics(); 
ik.setModel(robotModel); 


% Set IK tolerances 
ik.setCostTolerance(0.001). 
% ik.setCostTolerance(1.0); 
ik.setConstraintsTolerance(0.00001); 
% Set targets as cost in the cost function 
ik.setDefaultTargetResolutionMode(iDynTree.InverseKinematicsTreatTargetAsConstraintFull); 
% Use roll pitch yaw parametrization for the rotational part of the IK 
ik.setRotationParametrization(iDynTree.InverseKinematicsRotationParametrizationRollPitchYaw); 
ik.setVerbosity(3); 
ik.setDefaultTargetResolutionMode(iDynTree.InverseKinematicsTreatTargetAsConstraintNone); 


% Add position target  
ik.addPositionTarget(frameIdx, G_targetPos); 


% --------- Add starting point 
% As the IK optimization problem is a non-linear iterative optimization, the 
% optimization requires a starting point (to be assumed). Be aware 
% that this choice can influence the actual convergence of the algorithm 
jointsInitPosInRadians = iDynTree.VectorDynSize(); 
jointsInitPosInRadians.zero(); 
ik.setFullJointsInitialCondition(G_T_base, jointsInitPosInRadians); 


% --------- Solve the IK 
if ~ik.solve() 
    fprintf('
 Fail to solve IK!
') 
end 
G_H_base_optimized          = iDynTree.Transform(); 
jointPos_optimizedInRadians = iDynTree.VectorDynSize(); 
ik.getFullJointsSolution(G_H_base_optimized, jointPos_optimizedInRadians); 


 ~~~


Thanks a lot to Lorenzo Rapetti (@lrapetto) that implemented this feature in https://github.com/robotology/idyntree/pull/633 . 


## Acknowledgements 


Thanks to the contributors (either as code authors, code reviewers or by contributing documentation) of this version of iDynTree:  
* Francisco Andrade (@fjandrad) 
* Stefano Dafarra (@S-Dafarra) 
* Gabriele Nava (@gabrielenava) 
* Giulio Romualdi (@GiulioRomualdi)  
* Lorenzo Rapetti (@lrapetti) 
* Claudia Latella (@claudia-lat) 
* Silvio Traversaro (@traversaro) 


## Detailed ChangeLog  


### Added 
- Added a new function to `iDynTreeWrappers` for the function `getWorldTransformsAsHomogeneous`. 
- Added functions for having a MATLAB iDynTree Visualizer in `iDynTreeWrappers`. Some time optimization has been performed (https://github.com/robotology/idyntree/issues/659). 
- Added `bindings` for `getWorldTransformsAsHomogeneous` function. 
- Added function `getWorldTransformsAsHomogeneous` that gives a vector of Matrix4x4 based on a vector of strings containing the frame transforms. 
- Added `bindings` for handling `linkSolidShapes` properly (https://github.com/robotology/idyntree/issues/656). 
- Added `bindings` for `InverseKinematics` (https://github.com/robotology/idyntree/pull/633). 
- Implement `cbegin()` / `cend()` and `begin()` / `end()` methods for `VectorDynSize` and `VectorFixSize` (https://github.com/robotology/idyntree/pull/646). 
- Added CI for MacOS with `IDYNTREE_USES_OCTAVE` `ON`

title: Distro 2020.05 Released
summary: This is to let you know that we have just finalized our Software Distro 2020.05
description:
Hello @robotology/everyone  üëã 


This is to let you know that we have just finalized our **Software Distro 2020.05** üì¶ 


This is a major release that comprises **binary packages** as well. Therefore, follow the [instructions][1] available in the wiki to upgrade your system and/or download the new dependencies. 


You can find the tags composing this distro in our [Software Versioning Table][2]. 


The binaries cover the following platforms: 
- Ubuntu bionic 64-bits. 
- Ubuntu focal 64-bits. 
- Debian buster 64-bits. 
- Windows 10 64-bits.


#### ‚ö†Ô∏è Disclaimer 


Starting from [version 1.15.0 (25-FEB-2020)](https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/releases/tag/v1.15.0), we added the following dependency: 


``` 


ycm-cmake-modules 


``` 


The above package is distributed along with other icub packages by our repository, this package is now a dependency of the packages `icub-main` and `icub-common`.  


Moreover this new dependency needs a recent version of `cmake` (at least `3.12`). 


Where this version is not available in the distribution repositories (such as Ubuntu 18.04 bionic), when you try to install the icub-common package you'll see the following error: 


``` 
The following packages have unmet dependencies: 
icub-common : Depends: ycm-cmake-modules but it is not going to be installed     
Depends: cmake (>= 3.12.0) 
E: Unable to correct problems, you have held broken packages. 


``` 


To solve the above issue, you need to add the [official Kitware APT repository](https://apt.kitware.com/).





This distro is shipped with several update and fixes, including the ones listed hereafter: 


#### üÜï Updates 


- Added GH action for producing automatically the windows binaries installer at every release(https://github.com/robotology/robotology-superbuild/issues/335) 
- Added esdcan device in the Windows binaries installer: 
  - https://github.com/robotology/robotology-superbuild/issues/360 
  - https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/pull/656 
- Added support for OpenCV 4 for `cer` (https://github.com/robotology/cer/pull/114) 
- Modernization of `icub-firmware-shared`, which has become an actual library to be compiled: 
  - https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/pull/653 
  - https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/pull/650 
  - https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/pull/649 
  - https://github.com/robotology/icub-firmware-shared/pull/36 
  - https://github.com/robotology/icub-firmware-shared/pull/35 
  - https://github.com/robotology/icub-firmware-shared/pull/34 
- Added the new `icub-main` module `wholeBodyPlayer` that allows replaying prerecorded sequences through `yarpdataplayer` (https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/pull/654) 
- Added some `boost` ports to `robotology-superbuild-dependencies-vcpkg` 
- The Windows binary installer ships with support for native Gazebo simulations on Windows: 
  -  https://github.com/robotology/gazebo-yarp-plugins/issues/74#issuecomment-633059537 
  - https://github.com/robotology/robotology-superbuild/pull/412 


#### üßπ Cleanup 


- Removed all the `Find*.cmake` modules from `icub-main`, superseded by `ycm`, which is now a dependency(https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/pull/646) 
- Moved the configuration files of `r1` robots, from `cer` to `robots-configuration`: 
  - https://github.com/robotology/robots-configuration/pull/182 
  - https://github.com/robotology/cer/pull/116 
- Removed all the gtk-based modules from `icub-main`, they have been moved to https://github.com/robotology-legacy/icub-gtk-modules 
  - https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/pull/659 
  - https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/issues/606 


#### üêû Fixes 


- Fixed `iCubGui` on Windows: 
  - https://github.com/robotology/robotology-superbuild/issues/355 
  - https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/pull/657 
- Fixed `icub-main` python bindings: 
  - https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/issues/645 
  - https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/pull/655 
- Fixed `yarpview` in Windows binaries(https://github.com/robotology/robotology-superbuild/issues/354) 


[1]: https://wiki.icub.org/wiki/ICub_Software_Installation 
[2]: https://wiki.icub.org/wiki/Software_Versioning_Table

title: Distro 2020.02 Released
summary: This is to let you know that we have just finalized our Software Distro 2020.02
description:
Hello @robotology/everyone üëã This is to let you know that we have just finalized our **Software Distro 2020.02** üì¶ As already announced in #377, this is a major release that comprises **binary packages** as well. Therefore, follow the [updated instructions][1] available in the wiki to upgrade your system and/or download the new dependencies. You can find the tags composing this distro in our [Software Versioning Table][5]. The binaries cover the following platforms: - Ubuntu beaver 64-bits. - Debian buster 64-bits. - Windows 10 64-bits. Be careful since we now strictly require you to: 1. Install **CMake 3.12** as described in #364. 1. Rely on [**`YCM`**][2], which is now a mandatory dependency for `icub-main`. You'll find out more details in the [installation instructions][1]. #### ‚ö†Ô∏è Disclaimer We have changed the way we produce installers for Windows as we now officially make use of [`vcpkg`][3] to handle dependencies. We have been consolidating this process and thus there are still [known issues][4] we are going to definitely fix in the next distro. Should you need help, don't hesitate to get back to us! This distro is shipped with the updates and fixes reported hereinafter. #### üÜï Updates - All the robots contained in `robots-configuration` are compatible with the latest **Motion Control Version 6**.
‚ö™ Click to find the robots we specifically upgraded in this distro ü§ñ
  • iCubDarmstadt01
  • iCubEdinburgh01
  • iCubHeidelberg01
  • iCubLausanne02
  • iCubNancy01
  • iCubNottingham01
  • iCubSheffield01
  • iCubSingapore01
  • iCubTwente01
  • iCubHamburg01
- We cleaned up and made `icub-main` **OpenCV4 ready** as well as a number of sister projects we daily use as `icub-tutorials`, `icub-basic-demos`, `icub-tests`, `iol`, `himrep`, `segmentation` and a few more. - We completed the update of `icub-main` to the use of `std::mutex` in place of the deprecated `yarp::os::Mutex`. - We extended the _red-ball-demo_ to cover the case of robots where a physical torso is not available like `iCubChemnitz01`: - https://github.com/robotology/robots-configuration/commit/6bdfec9bb0b427edc5cbd551b76a17aa811c1552 fixed the matrix H0. - https://github.com/robotology/robots-configuration/commit/79ec8b1a6106013ac5d86b82ea5c1587b1c4ded4 added custom LIC. - https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/commit/facf98981c993bc97b110ff2c5f2facb90794294 allowed `iKinCartesianSolver` to deal with custom LIC, plus fixed handling of direct/reverse order w/ custom kin. #### üêû Fixes - We fixed `WBD` crash caused by `yarp::sig::Vector` move semantic: see https://github.com/robotology/yarp/issues/2192. - We also fixed spurious crashes of `iCub_SIM` due to an overload of calls to log directives: see https://github.com/robotology/icub-main/issues/637. [1]: https://wiki.icub.org/wiki/ICub_Software_Installation [2]: https://github.com/robotology/ycm [3]: https://github.com/microsoft/vcpkg [4]: https://github.com/robotology/robotology-superbuild/releases/tag/v2020.02 [5]: https://wiki.icub.org/wiki/Software_Versioning_Table
